bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK Executive Dr.
rector Roy Wilkins of the Ma
tional Association for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People has
requested Sargent Shriver, di-
rector of the anti-poverty pro-
gram, to rescind regulation
barring youths with police
records from the youth job corps.


DR.. Lewis Eiger, director OF
the agency's Office of Program
Development and Analysis Of the
Job Corps, said here earlier that
boys with police records would
not be accepted for the youth
camps planned in the Federal
anti-poverty drive.


In protesting Wilkins said
Hundreds of young people have
been arrested and convicted for
participation in peaceable civil
rights demonstrations. To ban
them would be to approve their
police records and the unconsti-
tutional local laws under which
they we're arrested"


''In addition" MIR. Wilkins
continued, there are thousands
of other boys from impoverished
homes who become involuntarily
or unwittingly involved in activi-
ties that lead to arrest. They
are potentially good citizens and
should not be denied opportunity
tO improve them SelVeS,"

NAACP HEAD


WANTS ARREST
STIGMA REMOVED

About |. IS million low-income
taxpayers will have no tax to pay
next year because of the new
minimum standard deduction
provision enacted this year.


George D. Patterson, District
Director of Internal Revenue.
said this provision will free
single individuals of any tax liza
bility until their income reaches
5000. Under the old law. tax
was due when income was So75.


MIR. Patterson said that for
married couple with no additional
exemptions filing a joint return
their income reaches $1,000.
Previously these couples had to
pay on income $l325.


The new minimum standard de-

duction amounts to $500 for sin
gle person and for a married
couple filing jointly plus $500
for each allowable exemption up
to a ceiling Of $1,000. For a
married person filing separate
return, the deduction amounts to
$500 plus $500 for each allowable
exemption up to a ceiling Of $500.


Taxpayers who do not itemize
deductions must use this mini
mum deduction If 1t exceeds the
10 percent standard deduction.


Tax savings of this new
provision are expected to amount
to about $500 million. APPROX
mately Is million taxpayers who
earn less than $4,000 a year
will benefit.

The cattleman, Julius Cesar,
of Halletsville, Texas, passed
through the city last week.


The Thanksgiving holiday was
filled with parties and dinners,
there was great fun all around
the city. Everyone enjoyed the
party given by the George Whit
fields in honor of their son
George Jr. and his wife from
San Francisco. Their house at
1880 E. Monroe was filled with
many visitors.


Hats off to the Merry Mixers
for another fine dance. This
group of women has been active
for IL years.


The hat show spoons ored by the
Alpha Kappa Alpha sororitywasa
good idea. We need to have more
programs of this kind.


Sgt. and Mrs. Booker T. Watt
of Anchorage, Alaska we're in
town to attend the funeal rites
of his father.


Calendars will be given to each
donor at a special building fund
program held at LIST Institutional
Baptist Church.


Edward Banks, publisher
editor of The Arizona Tribune is
resting at home after several
days in the hospital.


Mrs. Lille (Bunch) Conley re-
mains on the sick list. Lee M.
Smith is i'll, too.


Thought of the day : Always
think kind of everyone and see
how it makes you feel. Smith


Call AL 8-OO05 for news In
this column.

Thomas P .Wheelwright, Phoe-
nix advertising and public rela-
lions executive, ha been named
supervisor of the publicity and
communications division of the
Salt River Project Community
Relations Department.


Wheelwright, will be in charge
of an press relations, news re-
leases, publications, and for de-
velopment of internal and exter-
nal information programs.


Wheelwright, 46, began his
career as a newsman for the
Salt Lake City, Utah, Deseret
News Telegram, becoming as
sistant managing editor: He
then moved to Detroit and became
sales promotion manager for the
Chrysler Corporation.


In 1854 he was named public
relations director and plans
board member of Erwin, Wa sey,
Ruthrauff and Ryan. Inc, New
York City, the world S eighth
largest national advertising
agency.


While in New York he served
on the Mental Health Associa-
ton S National Advisory Coun-
Gil.


He moved to the Salt River
Valley in July. 1859, and became
active in advertising and public
relations with various firms
here before joining SRP in 1868.


BLINDNESS TOLL HIGH


From the time you started to
read this sentence until a year
from now, 10000 Americans will
have lost their eycsight, accord
ing to the National Society for
the Prevention of Blindness.

NEW YORK America pri-
vately-financed southern Negro
colleges are contributing an in
crea sing number of out standing
men and women to society, re-
ports a December Reader s Dr.
gest article, NEGRO Colleges:
Their Product and Promise"


Author James Daniel notes
some 70 of these colleges today
enroll about 100000 students.
Among their graduates have been
such distinguished Negroes IS
educator Booker T. Wa shington.
scholar w .E.B. Dubois, author
James Weldon Johnson, singer
Roland Hayes, Judge Thurgood
Marshall and the Rev. Martin
Luther King, 1864 winner of the
Nobel Peace Prize.


For the pa st twenty years fund
raising for 81 of the Negro
schools has been carried on CO.
operatively by the United Negro
College Fund, founded by DR..
Fred Patterson, then Pre- sident
of Alabama S famed Tuskegee
Institute. To date the Fund has
collected 46 million dollars for
it's member colleges, con-
tributing to each maximum ten
percent of expenses.


Using an incentive method
under which the more an in
dividual college raises inter-
nally the larger the share it
gets from gifts raised by the
U.N.C.F., the Fund has stimu-
lated substantial increa ses in
financial support by Negroes for
Negro colleges. Last year Ne
gro individuals and institutions
contributed ST. 100000 to the col
leges. A number of other u S.
college groups have copied the
Fund S innovation of joint financ-
ing, the Digest notes.


Academic standards among
Negro colleges are rising
rapidly, the article states;
graduates find ready admission to
top graduate schools and are
welcomed by many large national
corporations.


The colleges began just after
the civil War when New England
ssionaries poured southwark,
EARNED with Bibles and an In
cande scent conviction that the
children of slaves could be edu-
Gated"


Begun initially with bi-racial
admission policies, the schools
were forced to segregate by SOU
thern legislatures after the with
drawal of Union forces. Many
educators now foresee return
to bi-racial policies. Faculties
of the colleges are already
between 20% and 50% non-Negro,
and scholar ships are available on
a similarly open ba sis.


AIR CLOTHES INDOORS


The next best thing to hanging
clothes outdoors to air is hanging
them in closets equipped with
lower doors. The lowers permit
air to circulate freely to keeT
garments fresh.


~N|
